and this action brings him to the life of the World-to-Come.

Content: In days to come shall Jacob take root, Israel shall blossom and bud; And the face of the world shall be filled with fruitage.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: At all times let your garments be white, and let oil not be lacking upon your head [i.e., be constantly engaged in mitzvoth, so that if you die today, you will enter the world to come in peace.]

Content: Blessed is the L-rd, the G-d of Israel, from the world [i.e., from this world] until the world [to come]." And all the people said "Amen" and [gave] praise to the L-rd.

Content: ואל ימת AND LET HIM NOT DIE, in the world to come: that the incident of Bilhah be not remembered unto him (Siphre).

Content: Life and death are in the power of the tongue; those who love [to use] it [in the study of Torah] will eat its fruit [in the world to come].

] they would let [everyone] know that this world in front of the World to Come is like a vestibule in front of the banquet hall.

The verse states: “And he died there with the Ark of God” (II Samuel 6:7). Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Uzzah entered the World-to-Come, as it is stated: “With the Ark of God.” Just as the Ark exists forever, so too, Uzzah entered the World-to-Come.
And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: These are people who are considered important [yekarim] in this world and unimportant [kefuyim] in the World-to-Come. This is like the incident involving Rav Yosef

Content: But R. Johanan has said :  Who will inherit the world to come? He who unites the Ge'ullah of the evening to the Tefillah of the evening!

Content: It was a favourite saying of Rab :  Not like this world is the world to come. In the world to come there is neither eating nor drinking; no procreation of children or business transactions; no envy

Content: להיות עמה  TO BE WITH HER, in the world to come (Gehinnom) (Genesis Rabbah 87:6).

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And you shall keep My statutes and My judgments [(including what may be deduced, though not explicitly stated)], which a man shall do, and he shall live by them [in the world to come]; I am the L-rd [trusted to reward].

Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina said: The World-to-Come is not like this world. In this world, upon good tidings one recites: Blessed…Who is good and does good, and over bad tidings one recites: Blessed…the true Judge. In the World-to-Come one will always recite: Blessed…Who is good and does good. There will be only one mode of blessing God for tidings.
